stealing 5 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, 3 shillings, 2 sixpences, and 2 50l. notes, the monies of
George Eagles Marsden, and others, from the person of
William Simpson; and
JOHN REDDING
, for feloniously receiving the same, and being accessory after the fact.

WILLIAM SIMPSON . I am clerk to George Eagles Marsden, and two others, brewers, at Lewisham. On the 2nd of Oct., between nine and ten o'clock at night, I left the Horse and Groom, Blackheath-hill, somewhat the worse for liquor—I had two 50l. notes, six or seven sovereigns, and some silver, all in my left hand waistcoat pocket, in a bag—I got home about ten—I went down Blackheath-hill, and up Lewisham-lane—when I got home I missed my money—I was accosted on my way by a female—I cannot exactly recollect what took place—I was not accosted by more than one female, to my know
ledge—I had taken the money on my masters' account.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I believe you advertised the 50l. notes? A. I had bills printed, offering 10l. reward for their recovery—not for the conviction of the thief—I have not traced the notes.

ANN COOK . I am an unfortunate girl, but am now in an asylum at Bethnal-green—I know the prisoner Harman—she is a girl of the town, and lived in Mill-lane at the time with the male prisoner—I was in Lewisham-road about ten o'clock on 2nd Oct., and saw Mr. Simpson—Harman was with me—Mr. Simpson was walking along the road, rather tipsy—Harman went

up to him—he shoved her away, telling her he did not want anything to say to her—he gave her a fourpenny-piece—it was a moonlight night—he then came and took hold of my hand, and asked me to go down the road with him—I did not, as Harman shoved me away, and said she should do better with him than me—they stood about ten minutes together, and then she came away—they were about ten yards from me—she had him round the waist for about ten minutes—she then went down the road, and I went with her—she said she had two sovereigns, and if I came down she would give me a quartern of gin—I went with her to the Clock House, Broadway, Deptford—she went in there to the prisoner Redding, as she told me—I waited outside the door—I saw two pieces of white paper in her hand as she went into the Clock House—she put them down her bosom—they were rolled up—when shr came out of the Clock House she said she had given it to Johnny Redding—I thought she meant the two sovereigns—I saw Redding come out of the Clock House almost directly after her—he walked on the other side of the road—Harman had said she had no more money, before she saw the prosecu
tor—we had some rum at the Fountain, at the corner of Mill-lane, after we left the Clock House, a little after ten—she changed one shilling for the rum—she said she had no money at half-past eight, when I first met her, when she got a quartern of gin on trust at Lewisham-road, at the Ordnance Arms—I saw her next morning, and she said Johnny was gone out to buy a pair of Wellington boots—I told of this about a week after—I had not heard of the reward then.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What did she change? A. She changed a sovereign at the Swan, Blackheath-road, before she went to the Clock House—I have been living with a young man for about ten years—I am now twenty-four years old—I have walked the streets for the last eight weeks, as he is in trouble for beating a policeman—he is at Maidstone, and was tried here—I do not think he has been gone three months—I have not walked the streets for nine or ten months—my name is Cook, but they call me Byrne, sometimes, which is my grandmother's name—I was never called Match Kit—a relation of mine is called so—I have been in trouble for beat
ing the police and taking a drop of gin, nothing else—I was sent to Maidstone gaol for three months—a person named Richards was there at the same time for taking a bed-gown—my mother sent me there then—I was charged with stealing it, and sent to Maidstone for two months—I have been in custody three or four times, but have not been in trouble for these three years—the prosecutor was not a moment holding my hand—Harman would not let him—I made him no answer; Sophy spoke to me too quick—I went out that night about eight o'clock from Mill-lane—I left there with the prisoner—she walked rather before me, as she did not like Johnny to see me with her—I walked with her till ten o'clock, and went straight home after leaving her—I was at home a little after ten—we both went home together, and I went to bed—I informed the policeman of this about five days after, and before that told Carry Hawkins, who lives in the same house as me—the police have looked after her, but cannot find her—I did not see her that night—I saw her the night after the robbery.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. For the last ten years you lived with the young man? A. Yes—his name is Prebble—he is a boiler-maker—he has been in custody three times for beating the police—he was absent fourteen months once; at one time he was confined four months, and was sent from here six months—the fourteen months was five or six years ago—I when he is away I go out for my living on the town, but not all the time, as I went to the Union—he took me back when he came out of prison all the

three times—I was never charged with robbing a deaf and dumb man of a watch—I never heard of it—Mr. Molineaux put me in the asylum—I am to return there—my yonng man comes out about March—he was tipsy, and shoved against a policeman—I was present—I was not tipsy—I tried to get him away from the policeman, but did not strike him—I have not been living at a brothel—I charged a Mr. Martin with an assault—I did not tell her I would do for the prisoners, and get 10l., nor anything of the kind—I did not appear against her, as I went on the wrong day.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Is Mr. Molineaux the superintendent? A. Yes—I was about eight years old when I was at Maidstone about the gown—I was charged with stealing about five years ago—since that I have not been in custody, except for getting drank—I only saw Harman change one sovereign that night.
COURT. Q. You were charged with stealing about five years ago? A. Yes, the young man with me was also taken—the Magistrate dismissed the charge.

STEPHEN BROOKS (policeman.) On the night of 6th Oct. I saw the witness in Child's-lane, Lewisham, with another female, who I did not know, at ten o'clock—she was on the way from the Horse and Groom to Marsden's.

MARY EASTGATE . I live at the Ordnance Arms—I know Harman and Cook, and remember them having a quartern of gin at my house one evening, which they did not pay for—it was between nine and ten o'clock early in Oct.—I cannot say what day—I heard of this robbery a few days after.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was not Cook the person who asked for trust? A. I think it was, but cannot say.

MARY ANN FIGG . I live at the Swan, Blackheath-road. One Monday evening, at a quarter past eleven o'clock, I gave change for a sovereign to a person who was with Cook, and who I believe to be the female prisoner, but I have no knowledge of her, except serving her that time.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Ton know it was the other female took the change? A. No, I know it was the prisoner—I can
not positively say it was her—I believe so—I had seen Cook before—I did not suspect them to be women of the town—I do not know Carry Hawkins.

COURT. Q. What makes you believe the prisoner to be the person? A. I have no particular reason for saying so, only from what Cook said to me about a week or eight days after—I have no recollection of her features.

LOUISA HOOPER . I am an apprentice to Mr. Clay, a draper, Broadway, Deptford. On the morning of the 5th of Oct. the female prisoner came to look at a cloak—she said she could not have it until her husband returned with the money—she then went away, and returned in about an hour with five or six sovereigns, which she gave to me and took the cloak to show her husband—she afterwards came back again and paid 2l. 4s. for the cloak—I gave her the remainder of the money—next day she came with the male prisoner and purchased a dress—she said she would call her husband to have his opinion upon it—he came, and said he was no judge—the amount of her bill that day was 19s. 9d.—I saw her again next day, and she bought a bonnet for 6s.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you known her for any time? A. I had seen her before—I believe she was a customer at the shop—I never served her but once before—she then gave me silver—the value of the article she then bought was 16s. or 17s—I do not know of her having had other articles at our shop—I knew where she lived.
SAMUEL M'LELLAN , watchmaker, Deptford-bridge. On Saturday, the 7th

of Oct., Redding came to my shop, and paid me 12s. for a watch which he had bargained for before, and this was the balance due—the price of the watch was 1l. 12s—he had paid me the sovereign on the Thursday evening, I think.
JOSEPH LOCKYER CLOTHIER , clothes salesman, Flagon-row, Deptford. On the morning of the 3rd of Oct. I sold Redding a sort of printed velveteen coat for 13s—he gave me a sovereign—I gave him 7s. out.

JOHN SLATER , shoemaker, Church-street, Deptford. I sold Redding some boots about six weeks back—it was the second day of Croydon fair, I think, on a Tuesday—he paid me 10s—Martin was with him, and he borrowed 5s. of Martin—they went out together.

JAMES MARTIN , Mill-lane, Deptford. I have known Redding about eight years, and Harman three or four months—they both lived in my house, Harman in a ready-furnished room, and Redding was a nightly lodger, and slept along with my brother—he never slept with Harman to my knowledge—mine is a lodging-house—I was with Redding when he bought the pair of second-hand boots—it was on a Tuesday, I believe, about seven weeks ago, about Croydon fair time—I had heard him say a long time before that he would buy a pair of Wellington boots—I was with him the same day when he bought the second-hand coat of Clothier for 13s—I gave Maxwell, who lives next door to me, a coat which Redding had given me to take care of the night he was taken—I did not know there was any thing in it then—it was not the coat I had been with him to buy—I have lent him money from time to time, 4s., 5s., or 6s., and so on—he got his living by collecting old clothes, which he sold in Petticoat-lane—he borrowed 3s. of me to pay for the boots, and he paid me again the same day.
Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. Has he not generally paid you the same day when you have lent him money at other times? A. Yes—the clothes busines is sometimes very profitable.

MR. PAYNE. Q. When did he go to the Clock House to live as pot-boy? A. Before last Christmas—he was in the clothes line before that, ever since I have known him—he continued pot-boy till he hurt his hand about four months ago—he then went collecting old clothes again.
THOMAS MAXWELL , Mill-lane, Deptford. On the 10th of Oct. I received from Martin this coat and a gown-piece wrapped in it—I afterwards gave them to Lovell.

BENJAMIN LOVELL (police-sergeant R 15.) I received these from Maxwell—I took Harman into custody on the 10th of Oct., and told her I wanted her on suspicion of robbing a gentleman in the Lewisham-road—she said she knew nothing about it—I did not search her—I knew where she lived—I searched her lodging, and there found this cloak—she said she had been to Brighton with Johnny Redding—I went to the station about one o'clock in the morning, and found Redding there in custody—I told him I should charge him with receiving money, knowing it to be stolen, from Sophy—he said he did not know her—I told him from the woman he was living with—he said he was not living with any woman—I said, "I mean Soph "—he said, "I don't know her"—I said the girl he went to Brighton with—he said if he had been to Brighton it had nothing to do with me—he had this coat on.

JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 180.) I took Redding into custody on the 10th of Oct., at the Clock House, Deptford, about ten o'clock in the evening—I asked if he knew any thing of the prisoner Sophy—he said "Yes"—I asked if he did not live with her—he said "No"—I took him to the sta
tion, searched him, and found this watch—I asked where he got it—he said
he bought it of a Jew—I found in his pocket 4s. 6d. and a weighing machine—I knew him by sight—he was pot-boy at the Clock House once, and I have seen him since he left there.

SAMUEL M'LELLAN
re-examined. This is the watch he bought of me.

LOUISA HOOPER
re-examined. This gown-piece and cloak are like what I sold Harman.
NOT GUILTY .

260.
JAMES ARNOLD was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
John Jolliffe.

WILLIAM BROOKS . I am a Greenwich pensoiner. On the 23rd of Nov. I saw the prisoner and Jolliffe opposite the brew office—I heard the prisoner fall, and on turning round saw him lying with his head towards the deceased's feet—I saw the deceased stoop and shove the prisoner's head several times against the ground—he got up and struck the deceased, who struck him again—they entered into an angry parley, as far as I could see—I was on the opposite side of the way—the prisoner stood with his hand back in a threatening attitude, and after a few seconds he struck the deceased under the left ear—he stood a few seconds, and then fell on the side he received the blow—they endeavoured to raise him up, but he appeared to have no life in him, and died within a few seconds—the prisoner was handed over in custody to the guard.

LUCY LOCK , wife of John Lock, a pensioner. On the 23rd of Nov. I saw the prisoner and deceased getting up from the ground as I was advancing towards them—when they got up the deceased went backwards, the prisoner following him in a threatening manner, and said, "D—n your eyes I will give it to you presently, I would not mind knocking your head up against the brick wall"—they then advanced towards each other, and the prisoner struck the deceased on the left side of the head—he fell gradually on his knees, then on to his left side on the pavement, and died immediately—I saw him die—he appeared about seventy years old.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY, Q. In what condition was the prisoner? A. Apparently very tipsy.

ROBERT WHITMORE CLARK . I am assistant-surgeon at Greenwich-hos
pital. On the 24th of Nov. I saw the deceased's body, and examined the head—I found a very slight mark on the left temple—on opening the head, I found nothing worthy of remark under that mark—the lungs were con
gested in the highest degree, which I believe to be the cause of death, conse
quent on organic disease of the heart—the slightest exertion would be sufficient to produce it—I believe the blow he received might produce that excitement, which would cause the congestion—there was a diseased heart originally, and the blow coming upon that caused the death—the excitement threw an increased quantity of blood to the heart—he might have died with
out the blow—I am not able to say that the blow killed him—there must have been some excitement—passion might have occasioned his death, exclu
sive of the blow.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you have known such cases in your expe
rience? A. Frequently—it is a common cause of death.
NOT GUILTY .

261.
GEORGE MYERS and
JAMES GRIFFITHS were indicted for
stealing 4 pence; the money of
Edward Swinyard; and that Myers had been before convicted of felony.

JANE CHRISTIE SWINYARD . I am the wife of Edward Swinyard, a baker, of New-row, Deptford. On Friday, the 24th of Nov., about half-past eleven o'clock, I caught a glimpse of some one from my yard—I went into the shop, and there found Myers on the counter, with his hand in the till—I said, "What do you do at my till?"—he jumped up off the counter, and said, "I was not at your till"—I had put four penny pieces in it just before, and they were gone, and I saw the money in his hand.
Myers. It was the money I went in with. I did not put my hand into the till.

TIMOTHY DARLEY . I followed the prisoners from Rotherhithe, which is upwards of a mile from the prosecutor's—I saw them looking in at the pro
secutor's shop—Myers then went in—I afterwards saw Griffiths leave the shop-window, and in the meantime Mr. Swinyard came in and took Myers, who was in the act of taking the money out of the till—I took Griffiths back to the shop, and gave him in charge.

JAMES MAHONY (policeman.) I took Myers, and found on him a knife, a fourpenny-bit, and four penny pieces in his hand—he slipped them into his pocket—they dropped down through his trowsers, and I picked them up.

DANIEL M'PHERSON (policeman.) I produce a certificate of Myers' for
mer conviction—(read)—he is the person.

MYERS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

GRIFFITHS—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

262.
EDWARD WARD was indicted for
stealing 20 crowns, 120 half crowns, 150 shillings, 80 sixpences, and 30 groats; the monies of
Samuel Holmes, his master; and
THOMAS RAFFERTY
for feloniously receiving the same, well-knowing them to have been stolen, &c.: to which

WARD pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined One Year.

HENRY TEMPLE . I am in the employ of Mr. Holmes, at Deptford. On the 21st of Oct. I heard Ward say to Mr. Holmes, that Mr. Stanley would be obliged to him to let him have 30l. till the following Tuesday, which he was to take him when he went for his orders—I delivered him a parcel of silver, which Mr. Holmes gave me.

SAMUEL HOLMES . I delivered the parcel, containing twenty crowns, 120 half crowns, 150 shillings, eighty sixpences, and thirty groats, to Temple—Ward was in my service, and was to deliver it to Mr. Stanley.
ABSALOM JOHN STANLEY . Ward did not bring the 30l. of silver to me—I have not received any part of it.

MARIA ANN BAX . I keep the Star at Canterbury—between six and seven o'clock in the evening of the 25th of Oct., the prisoners and two men arrived at my house with a horse and cart—the prisoners asked for beds, and slept there—in the morning they got up, and Rafferty asked if I could give him gold for silver—he produced 15l. in silver, and I gave him fifteen sovereigns for it.

JAMES EPPS (police-constable C 5.) I apprehended tne prisoners at Can
terbury, and charged them with absconding with 30l. in silver from Deptford—when we got to the station, Rafferty said that they were the boys, and they might as well speak the truth—Ward said, "I am the boy that took the money"—I found on Rafferty eight sovereigns, five half crowns, a silver scent-box, a gold ring, and a knife.
Rafferty's Defence. He met me. I did not know about the money when it was taken; he asked me to go with him.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

263.
JOHN WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 1 1/4 lbs. weight of bacon, value 7d.; the goods of
Catherine Clark.

WILLIAM CLARK . I am in the service of my mother, Catherine Clark, and live at Woolwich—about twelve o'clock on the 27th of Oct. I missed a piece of bacon—Mr. Drew gave me a description of the man who took it—I saw the prisoner go into a public-house—I ran to the policeman and told him—I found the bacon in the public-house—it was cooked.

JOHN DREW . I am assistant to Mr. Stewart, a druggist—I saw the pri
soner take a piece of bacon from Mr. Clark's shop, and put it under his coat.

THOMAS BARNS THOMPSON (police-constable R 12.) I went into the public-house and saw the prisoner eating the bacon—I said, "What is this?"—he said, "Some I brought from London with me"—I said, some had been taken from Mr. Clark's shop—this is Mr. Groves the Magutrate's handwriting—(read)—"The prisoner says, 'I stole the bacon because I was hungry.'"
Prisoner's defence. I did not take it; while I was waiting in the room, an old lady opposite said, if you say you took it because you were hungry they will let you off, that is the reason I said so.

JOHN DREW
re-examined. There were greasy marks on his coat, exactly on the spot where I saw him put the bacon—I was not above three yards from him when he took it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Two Months.

264.
GEORGE HARRIS was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

265.
MICHAEL SMITH was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. BODKIN and ESPINASSE conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN COOPER , licensed victualler, Deptford. On Sunday afternoon, the 12th of Nov., the prisoner came to my house for a glass of gin, which came to 2d.—he gave me a half-crown—I gave him change, and he left—I put the half-crown in the till—I am sure there was no other there—in less than five minutes I looked at it again—no one had been to the till in the mean time—I found it was bad—I marked it and put it on the shelf—no one knew where it was—it remained there till Lovell came—on the 20th I gave it him from the same place—I am sure the prisoner is the man.
Prisoner. I got a little drink and was not aware of it, Witness. He was sober.
BENJAMIN LOVELL (police-sergeant R 15.) On the 20th of Nov. I received this half-crown from Cooper—I took the prisoner in High-street, Deptford—he said he knew nothing about it.

THOMAS JOSEPH HUNT . I keep the Fox, King-street, Deptford. On the 18th of Nov., a little after nine at night, the prisoner came for a glass of gin—he gave me half-a-crown—I saw it was bad—I said, "This is a bad one"—he said, "If so, I took it of my master in part of wages"—he then gave me a good one—I gave him change—I retained the bad one and sent for a policeman, marked it in his presence, and gave it him—he took the prisoner.

JAMES DEAN (police-constable R 319.) I was called to Hunt's, and took the prisoner in charge—I received a half-crown from Mr. Hunt, which he marked—I afterwards gave it to the inspector—the charge was not pressed, and the prisoner was let go.
SAMUEL EDWARD FREEMAN (police-sergeant R 5.) On the 18th of Nov., the prisoner was brought to the station—I received this half-crow from Dean.
MR. JOHN FEILD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These are both counterfeit, and both cast in one mould.
Prisoners Defence. I got it for my wages; I did not look whether it was bad or good.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Six Months.

266.
RICHARD BRUMHEAD was indicted
for feloniously killing and Slaying
Richard James Maddon.

THOMAS MADDON , hatter, King's-court, Union-street, Borough. On the 28th of Oct., about one o'clock in the day, I sent my son, Richard James, into Princes'-street—he was about nine years old, and was in perfect health—I next saw him about five or six minutes after, in a doctor's shop, in
sensible, covered over with blood—I went with him to Guy's Hospital—two policemen and two other men assisted him—he died at half-past six that evening—I came away about five minutes before he died—I did not see him again—I saw his body on the Monday.

JAMES BURBERRY , shoemaker, Union-street. On the 28th of Oct., at one o'clock in the day, I was in Union-street, and saw the prisoner and a boy named Bates, and the deceased, playing on the opposite side of the road—they had a dog with them—the prisoner was setting the dog on Maddon—he ap
peared alarmed, and ran backwards away from it—as he was running back
wards, Bates followed him and told the dog to bite him—he still continued to set the dog on, and as the boy was running backwards, he ran with his back up against the shaft of a cart, which knocked him down, and the wheel im
mediately went over his head—he was picked up by the man who was driving and a gentleman who I do not know—I heard the prisoner say nothing but "Bite him, bite him;" on that the dog jumped up on his person—when the boy went under the wheel the dog was in the road close by his feet—he did not take hold of the boy at all—he was taken to a surgeon's in Union-street, and from thence to the hospital.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. Did not the boy appear to be playing in the first instance? A. Yes—the dog was a brown and white spaniel, half-bred—I cannot say that the prisoner was laughing when he said "Bite him"—he appeared in the act of playing—I did not hear him cry out, "Mind the cart."

BENJAMIN BATES . I live in Union-street. On the 28th of Oct. I was in Union-st.—not on the same side with Maddon—the prisoner called me over—there was a dog there—Maddon was coming up towards us, and Brumhead called him butter-fingers—his thumb was tied up—then Brumhead set the dog on him—he said, "Bite him, bite him"—the boy appeared to be fright
ened—the dog went towards him, and he went walking backwards—the dog followed him up, but did not bite him—the boy ran, and went about a yard and half before he came to the wheel, when the shaft knocked him down, and the wheel went over him—I did not see him afterwards.
Cross-examined. Q. You all three knew each other very well? A. Yes—I knew the dog very well—he used to play with Maddon sometimes—when he was running back, the prisoner said, "Mind the cart"—it was a
dust-cart—I think the dust-man was at the horse's head, leading the horse—I am not sure he was close to the horse—it was in open daylight.
NOT GUILTY .

267.
EDWARD DWYER was indicted
for the wilful murder of
James Dwyer.

JOHN SPELLING . I am a labourer, and live at Green-bank, Tooley-street. On 24th Oct, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I was at Havill's public-house, the King's Head, Green-bank—I went into the tap-room, and saw several people there—the prisoner was there when I went in, smoking his pipe—he had a pint of ale and a glass before him on the table—I knew him before—he filled me a glass of ale, which I drank—-another working man went in with me—the prisoner drank with us both—I cannot tell how much he drank, but we had three pots of beer between four of us—the wife of the man who went with me had come in before we had done drinking—after being there some time, several people came in—the prisoner's wife came in a little before nine, with a baby in her arms, and her mother came in directly after—when his wife came in she put the baby out of her arms into the prisoner's arms, and blowed him up—she scolded him—I cannot tell her exact words, but she got hold of the hair of his head behind, and punched him in the face very hard—I cannot tell how many times—I think thirteen or fourteen times in the face—I cannot recollect what she said at the time, but she was crying, and was very much bad tempered with him—I do not recollect her calling him names, but the mother called him a murderer, a Greenacre, a man-eater, and a whoremonger, and, after her calling him these names, he called her a b—y w—c—she then ran and got hold of a quart pot, abused him as much as she could, came towards him, and hit at him with the pot—I got hold of her, and told her neither man or woman in the house should injure him—I prevented her striking him—his wife and mother kicked up a gallows row, and at last the landlord turned them out—the prisoner then had the baby in his arms, and was smoking his pipe—he shed tears, and said, "Tears cannot Help but come down"—after that he went outside the door, as far as the corner of the house, with the baby in his arms—I told him to come into the tap-room again, and we would have another pot of beer, and to bring the baby in, as it was too late at night to have it out—he came in, and when he got in a woman offered to take charge of the child—he gave it her, and she suckled it—she did not keep it above two minutes, I think, because she had a baby of her own crying—when he had the child back, there was a little girl, an aunt of the child, there—we told him to give the child to the aunt, and she would take good care of it—he gave it her—she had it for a few minutes—the aunt's mother came in and blowed her up—the aunt was the sister of the prisoner's wife—the mother-in-law came in and blew the aunt up, and hit her on the shoulder—she came in again, and made the girl give the child to the prisoner, which she did—they kicked up a row, and the publican turned the lot of them out—the prisoner shed tears, and said again, "Tears cannot help to come down"—when we had been there some time, he said he wanted to go out—we did not want him to go out, fearing the child, which he still had, would catch cold—he told Havill, the publican, he insisted on going out—Havill told him to give the child to the woman who had suckled it before—he said he would not, and nobody but himself should do for the child, it was his child, and he would do for it himself, and nobody else should—he asked Havill's liberty to go out—Havill spoke to him—I cannot say what he said, and we got up to let him pass by—he went as far as the bar,

and stood about a minute, with the baby in his arms—he took it up, cuddled it to his breast as near as he could—I was standing close to him, and the next thing I heard was the baby's head come on the bar—I was not above a foot and a half from him—I saw the baby's head coming on the bar.

Q. He had hold of the child at the time its head came on the bar? A. Yes, I think he had, but I cannot prove that, as my eyes dazzled when I heard its head coming on the bar—I saw nothing before that—the child's pole came on the bar, and the child came down on the ground—I took it up, and the prisoner held it by the clothes at the same time, and I said, "The baby is dead"—the report went round that it was killed—the baby's mother came in—I gave it to her, and she went to the doctor's with it.

COURT. Q. At the time you heard and saw the baby coming on the bar, had the prisoner hold of it? A. Yes—I saw the pole of its head coming on the bar, and the head slipped down—I stooped down, and picked the baby up—the prisoner held it round the hips at the time its head came against the bar, at far as I could understand.

MR. PAYNE. Q. How did the head come against the bar? A. I cannot tell whether it was his good will or accident, or how—I do not think I saw anything more than I have said—I do not recollect it if I did—before he left the tap-room to go to the bar, he said a good many things I could hardly make any meaning of—I did not hear him say anything while he stood at the bar, that I can re
member now—before he left the tap-room he said a good many things I do not recollect, and some I do recollect—he had his finger on some beer that was spilt on the table, and was writing figures, or something—I could hardly understand what—he talked about starvation, or something—he said, "When you see the jaw-bones moving, it is very queer;" and after that he said blood on a brick wall looked very funny, and if there was a bullet on a brick wall there would be blood, and blood on a brick wall looked very funny—as far as I recollect, that was all—this was before the child's head came against the bar—I think it was better than half an hour after the mother had gone out that the child's head came against the bar.

COURT. Q. What was he doing when he stood at the bar with the child in his arms, was he doing anything with the child? A. No more than taking care of it, as far as I could expect a man to take care of it—he appeared to be cuddling it at the time, and I saw him take it suddenly by the thigh—I saw no change in his position.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. How long had you been in the tap-room before the wife and mother came in? A. I think about half an hour—the child's mother was carrying it—she came in in a great passion, and put it into his arms, not steadily—I cannot say she threw it into his lap—she was sitting down, and put it into his arms—it was asleep when he stood with it at the bar, it was quite quiet—I had heard it screaming about ten minutes before—it was in the prisoner's arms at the time the mother was striking him—he did not offer the slightest violence to her all the time—if she got the child back from him again, I did not see it—the mother-in-law did not strike him—she went to strike him with a quart pot—I would not allow her—all the blows the wife gave him were on his face, and as hard as she could hit—I cannot say whether the old woman, when she came the second time, called the child a little nasty faggot—I saw her hit him—she abused him, and came in in rather a bad temper—I am quite sure almost immediately before the child's head came against the bar he was cuddling it close to his bosom—he cried bitterly two or three times in the tap-room—he seemed to me to be wandering when in the tap-room, saying, when a man's jaw was moving it was a queer thing, or something like that.

COURT. Q. Take up that book, and show us how be held the child? A. Like this—he had one hand under the child's loins, and the other under its thigh, its head hanging over his arms—he cuddled it up, with its face to his face—I was looking at him all the time—I think he held it all the time till the head came against the bar—I could not see any change in his manner of holding it before the head came on the bar—I saw the pole of the head come on the bar—my eyes dazzled, and I could hardly tell how he held it at the time—I stooped down and took it up—I was looking at the publican in the bar, heard the violence of the blow, and picked the child up.

GEORGE STEAD , tailor, Magdalen Circus, Bermondsey. On the night of the 24th of Oct. I was at Mr. Havill's public-house, at Green-bank—I went there between eight o'clock and half-past, and saw the prisoner sitting in the tap-room—I had never seen him before—a person I understood was his wife was with him—they were falling out—he had a baby on his knee, and offered it to the mother—she would not take it, and he put it on his knee again—I walked up to the fire, and a woman I understood to be the mother-in-law called him a Greenacre and murderer, and he called her a w—she then seized a quart pot up to strike him, or throw at him—I took it out of her hand—Havill came in, and turned them out—Spelling also prevented her striking him—after they were put out a woman took the baby from the pri
soner, and gave it to a girl fourteen or sixteen years old—the prisoner sat down, and he could not help dropping a tear or something—he was sitting by me—the mother-in-law came in, and made the girl give the child back to the prisoner—he took it, and put it on his knee—Havill came, and turned the mother-in-law and girl out—he then told the prisoner to go out—he went out quietly with the child in his arms, and returned again in about five minutes, and sat down by my side with the baby—he said the child was his, and be would do for it, and with the same breath he said he would be the death of it before the morning—he said; Stood sprinkled on a brick wall would look funny in the morning—I tapped him on the shoulder, told him to take a fool's advice, and not revenge himself on a poor innocent baby—he made no reply—he appeared vexed—he sat a while, then said he would go out—the company in the house said he should not—they gave no reason—he called Mr. Havill as a witness that they would not let him out, and then they let him go out—he went out of the tap-room to the bar—I drank my beer off, and went—the prisoner was standing at the bar—I stood with my face towards the bar—the child was then in the prisoner's arms—he took the child, I cannot say whether he took it by its legs or clothes, as it had long clothes, but he took it, and struck it on the counter of the bar.

Q. Did you observe the effect of that blow on the child? A. It was a blow on the head—he then said, "I have done it; I have left one behind, now take me"—he then went into the tap-room, and sat himself down—I thought he was crying—he said he always stuck to his word—I remained there till the constable came, and Mr. Havill gave him in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. How far do you live from Havill's house? A. About 100 or 200 yards—I had been working at my trade that day—this was the first time I had been in the public-house that day—there might be a dozen or more persons in the tap-room when the prisoner made the observation I mention—I saw Donovan there—I sat next to the prisoner on one side at one time—I do not know who was on the other side—Spelling was not quite opposite to him—there was a table between them—when the prisoner said he would be the death of the child that morning, Spelling was in the room, and about as near to him as I was—there were several persons by the bar when I saw what I have stated—the landlord was there, but I do not believe he saw the blow struck—Spelling was there—I did not see the barmaid or any
female at that moment—there were several men there—Francis Brown was drinking with me, and he came out with me.

Q. Was not the prisoner's expression, "The child is my own, I am its father, and will do for it as I always have done?" A. No—I will not swear it—he said, "The child is mine, and no one shall touch it; I will do for it"—I do not know that he appeared incoherent and wild—I did not hear him say anything about starvation, and how funny it was to see people's jaws work—I did not hear a good deal he said, I dare say, as I was talking to my friend.

DANIEL DONOVAN . I am a labourer, and live in Griffiths'-rents, Tooley-street—I was at Havill's public-house, on the 24th of Oct., between eight and nine o'clock—I went into the tap-room, near the fire—I have known the prisoner at least fifteen or sixteen years—I went to school with him—I was in the room before he came in—I saw him rather excited in his mind, rather irritated in his mind and spirits—I was in the tap-room writing a letter before he came in—he came in, called for a pint of ale, sat down in the box where I was, and poured me out a glass of ale—I drank it, and he drank a glass himself—I asked him to drink out of my pot, which he did—he remained a few mi
nutes, then went to another company—I still remained writing—the mother
in-law came in and abused him, called him Greenacre, a murderer, and names not fit to be used—the wife came in afterwards with the young infant in her arms, put it into the prisoner's lap, and said, "There is your child, take care of it, I will have no more to do with it; I will work, and get my own living"—she then turned round to him, and struck him several blows on the face and head—the prisoner began to cry, and said he was in the power of the law, and did not wish to strike her, he had come out on two 20l. bail, and what would the men do who had bailed him out?—the publican came and turned the mother-in-law and wife out—the prisoner still remained in the tap-room, with the child in his arms, for a quarter of an hour or more—a younger sister of his wife's came in, and he gave the child to her—it seemed to be crying—the mother-in-law then came in, and began to blow the girl up for taking the infant—she gave it back to the prisoner—the mother-in-law came to the table where I was, and took up a quart pot to strike the prisoner—it was taken out of her hand by a witness—the publican came, and turned both the women out—the child remained with the prisoner—a woman in the company said, "Give me the child, I will take care of it"—the prisoner replied, he would take care of it, he had always done for the child, and would do so now—he then rose from the table with it in his arms, and said to the publican, "I want to go out, and these people won't let me go away"—some persons had tried to prevent his going out—the publican desired them to let him go out—he went out of the side-door with the child in his arms—and returned into the tap-room in a moment or so, with the child in his arms, and remained in the tap-room four or five minutes—he then went to the bar out of the tap-room, and stood outside the bar with the child in his arms—I remained in the tap-room—he returned to the tap-room a minute or two, and returned to the bar again with the child—the tap-room door had closed, and I heard a cry outside that the child was murdered, but I still remained in the tap-room.

Cross-examined. Q. You have known him from a child, did it not strike you that night there was something very different from what you had before seen? A. Yes, he seemed very much down-hearted, very much excited in spirits—he did not keep his head up at all—when I knew him he was always jovial—he was always very fond of his children—I suppose his wife was rather the worse for liquor that night—the mother-in-law appeared the same—when she came in the second time, and saw the child in the other daughter's
hands, she called her a young faggot, and told her to give it back to the prisoner.

GEORGE HAVILL . I keep the Old King's Head, Green-bank, in the parish of St. Olave's. On the night of the 24th of Oct. the prisoner came in about eight o'clock, went into the tap-room, and called for a pint of ale—I afterwards saw some women come to him—I heard the mother-in-law call him a Green
acre and a murderer—I saw the wife hit him right and left it hard as she could, abont the face—the child was on his lap at that time—I turned the women out—the mother-in-law called him a Greenacre, a murderer, a man
eater, a woman-eater, and another expression almost too bad to mention—every thing she could say against him she did—after I had put the women out, the prisoner remained in the tap-room with the child—I did not see the women again till after the child was killed—about a quarter of an hour after they were gone I said to the prisoner, "You had better leave my place"—he said, "Master, I won't hurt you nor any one else," and went out very quietly indeed with the child for about five minutes, then came back very quietly, went into the tap-room, remained about five or ten minutes, and the people would not let him go out—he applied to me—I was called, and said, "It is all right, you had better let him go out"—he came out of the tap-room in the front of the bar with the child in his arms—I was inside the bar—I had occasion to leave the front of the bar for not a minute, and went behind a curtain which is acrost the bar, sad when I had been there about a minute, I heard a woman scream out that the child was murdered—I went in front of the bar, and the prisoner said, "I told you I should do it; I am always as good as oy word; I shall be hung at the Old Bailey; I hope every one will come and see me hung"—he went into the tap-room, laid himself down on the bench, and began to cry—I went for a policeman—I remained at the tap-room door till the policeman came, and gave him into custody—the counter in front of my bar is a kind of shelf, about eighteen inches wide, made of pewter—I considered him sober when he came into my house—I think I had teen him two days before, he and his wife came together for a pint of ale—I have known him five or six years.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you first repeat the expression which you say the prisoner used about being hung at the Old Bailey, &c.? A. I men
tioned it at Union-hall—I think you will find it in my deposition—I will swear I recollected it when I was at Union-hall.

Q. Did not be say, "I hare done it, I have done what I said I would, I will go in and sit down, and I will give myself up?" A. No, not those words exactly—I am positive he said what I have stated—I will swear it—I was sober—I should say a dozen peeple heard him say this, customers—Donovan, Spelling, and Stead are not regular customers.

GEORGE TOMPKINS (police-constable M 166.) I went to Mr. Havill's on the 24th of Oct., about half-past nine o'clock at night—I was not sent for—it is on my beat-—I went in, seeing a mob round the door—the prisoner was sitting down, leaning on the table—he was gives into my custody by Havill—I took him to the station—in going along he said to me, "I shall go to the Old Bailey for what I have done"—he was sober, but appeared very much agitated—I took him part of the way, but he got so very violent, I was obliged to call the assistance of another constable—I had hold of him.

Cross-examined. Q. He talked extremely loud, did not he? A. I do not know about talking loud—he plunged himself about, and kicked about, and flung his arms about—he did not kick me, nor tear his hair.

MARY ROBINSON . I know the prisoner, and his children and wife. On the 24th of Oct., at night, I saw his wife with a child about three months old, in Bermondtey-street, not a minute's walk from Havill's—I accompanied
her to the hospital with it—it was alive when the surgeon examined it at the hospital.
ELLEN CANTRAM . I am related to the prisoner—the mother of the child is my daughter—I saw it at the hospital next day—its name was James Dwyer.
Cross-examined. Q. Pray were you in the public-house on that night? A. Yes—I heard the mother say he had given her 9s. a night or two before this, to buy the child a hat—she did not buy it.

EDWARD COCK , surgeon, St. Thomas-street, Southwark. On the night of the 24th of Oct. I was sent for to Guy's-hospital, where I am assistant-sur
geon, and saw a child who was brought there—the woman who brought it said it was her child—I examined, and found its head very much swollen and mis-shapen—a great swelling on the right side, produced by extravasation of blood—I had no doubt the brain was injured, and that there was a fracture of the skull—it was alive then—I did all I could for it, and left it in care of the dresser and sister of the ward—I hardly expected it would live more than two hours—I saw it dead next morning—I attributed its death to the injury on the head—I made a post mortem examination, which entirely confirmed my opinion.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you find a fracture on both sides of the head? A. Both.
COURT. Q. Could that both be produced by one blow? A. I think so—it certainly would be a violent blow—it might be produced by any collision with a hard substance.

JURY. Q. Could it have happened if the child had fallen from a man's arms accidentally? A. I think such an injury might have been inflicted by its falling directly on its head on the ground, from a certain height—if it fell directly on the vertex of its head, four or five feet, on a stone or hard floor, it is possible such a fracture might have been produced.

GEORGE HAVILL
re-examined. The front of the bar is about three feet six inches from the ground.
MR. WILKINS. Q. Was Donovan by when these observations were made by the prisoner? A. He stood by his side when he said he should be hung at the Old Bailey—they were all standing about.

MR. COCK re-examined. Q. Suppose it had fallen from a man's arms on to a place three feet six inches from the ground, on a substance harder than lead, do you think that would produce the fracture? A. I cannot swear it would not, but consider it improbable.

MR. WILKINS to DANIEL DONOVAN. Q. You was present immediately after the child's head had been on the metal; did the prisoner say he had said he would do it, he was always as good as his word, that he should be hung for it at the Old Bailey, and hoped every one would come to see him? A. No, I did not hear any such words—he said, "It is done, now take me, "—he went into the tap-room, and laid his head on the table—I saw no more of the proceeding.
JURY. Q. But you was not at the bar at all? A. No—I was not at the bar.

GEORGE STEAD
re-examined. I did not see the child fall on the ground—I never saw it on the ground—I took it up before it got on the ground, after it had been on the counter—Spelling caught it and took it away, either by its legs or clothes—I never saw it drop from the counter on the ground, on its head.

JOHN SPELLING
re-examined. I heard the head come on the counter—I caught hold of the child before it went on the floor—I am almost sure I picked it up before the head came on the floor—it went very near it.

MR. WILKINS. Q. Did the prisoner say he had done it; he should go to the Old Bailey, and be hung for it, and hoped they would come to see him hung? A. I did not hear it, but I followed the child's mother out.

GUILTY .—
Death. Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy, on account of the strong excitement.

268.
WILLIAM ANDERSON and
JAMES GREEN were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Aldous at Bermondsey, with intent to steal.

JOHN ALDOUS . I am landlord of the Valentine and Orson public-house, Long-lane, in the parish of Bermondsey. I have a cellar, the door of which is outside the premises—it is usually secured by four bolts inside. On the 26th of Nov., at ten o'clock at night, I saw that door bolted safe—I went to bed about a quarter before eleven—about two o'clock a constable's rattle awoke me—I got up, went to the door, went into the cellar, and found a board forced off the door from the outside, that would enable a person without to draw baek the bolts, and let themselves in—none of my property was stolen—getting into the cellar would enable the parties to get into the house—I afterwards went to the station, and saw the prisoners in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where does the cellar-door open upon? A. Into the street—I am sure nobody opened the door in the course of business after I saw it safe—the piece of board that was broken was nailed on—that was the only protection the door had—I should think the door was about an inch thick—I have no partner.
COURT. Q. Did the board, before it was broken, form part of the door? A. Yes—I observed marks of an instrument on it.

THOMAS OCKFORD (police-constable M 277.) On the night of the 26th of Nov., a few minutes before two o'clock, I was near the prosecutor's house—I heard a rustling, like some person treading on coal, in a lane that runs down the side of the prosecutor's house—I went and found a piece of board about nine inches wide, had been wrenched off the prosecutor's cellar-door by some instrument—I looked down into the cellar, and perceived a faint light on the wall, and in a minute or two I heard footsteps faintly inside, and whispering—I went for assistance, and got police-constable M 51—on coming back to the cellar-door they had a light inside—I heard them whispering quite plainly, and called to them to come out several times—the light was suddenly extinguished, and the prisoner Green made a spring through the broken door, and tried to escape—I seized him—he struggled with me a great deal—he did not succeed in getting from me—I sprang my rattle—police-constable M 195 came up, and assisted to secure Green—while doing so he called to me that another man was coming from the cellar—Green was still struggling with us—I did not myself see Anderson come out of the cellar, but I took him as he was then rising off his feet from the pavement, about a yard from the cellar-door—we took them both to the station—I found some lucifer matches on Anderson.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure Green came out of the cellar? A. Quite—I had never seen him before—I will swear he was quite sober—I am quite certain I did not mistake him for another person who got away—he got out of the cellar—I did not go down into the cellar.
JAMES NINER (police-constable M 51.) I assisted Ockford in securing Green—he came to the door, and we secured him—he struggled, but never got away from me.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see him come out of the cellar? A. Yes—the light was out before he came out—I never saw him before—we seized him exactly at the door, and he never escaped from our hold.

ROBERT WOODS (police-constable M 185.) I was on duty in Long-lane—my attention was called by a rattle to the prosecutor's premises—when I got there I saw Green struggling with Ockford and Niner—they at length secured him—in the struggle I saw Anderson in the act of coming out of the cellar—his head and shoulders were out—I said to Ockford, "Go back and secure him, and I will take the other to the station"—I did so—Ockford had hold of him—I saw enough of him to say he is the man.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you go into the cellar? A. After we came back—there were barrels of beer there, wine, and pipes leading up into the bar, and coals.

DANIEL HALEY (police-constable M 181.) I assisted my brother con
stables in securing the prisoners—I afterwards picked up this crow-bar (produced) close by the cellar-door outside—I compared it with some marks on the cellar-door—it corresponded exactly—in the cellar I found a piece of candle, which appeared to have been recently lighted.

(George Appleton, cab-proprietor, Hertford-road, Haggenton; George Kite, cab-proprietor, 3, Gloucester-street, Curtain-road; William Hobbs, shoemaker, 3, Hackney-road; and—Costello, tobacconist, 13, Kingsland-road, deposed to Green's good character.)

ANDERSON—
GUILTY . † Aged 25.

GREEN—
GUILTY . † Aged 30.

269.
ALFRED WALKER was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles Lodge, at Camberwell, with intent to steal.

CHARLES LODGE . I am a surgeon, and live in Rye-lane, Peckham, in the parish of Camberwell. On the night of the 30th of Nov. I was out on business—I returned home about half-past three o'clock, and I let myself in with a latch-key—I went up stairs to bed after having chained and secured the door—after I had been in bed a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes I fancied I heard a slight noise outside my chamber door—I listened, and heard it repeated in my dressing-room adjoining my bed-room—I opened the door, and saw some person there—I closed with him immedi
ately, and tried to secure him—he resisted as much as possible, and was as much as I could manage—after calling out to Mr. Lodge and the servants, further assistance was procured, and he was eventually secured—it was the prisoner—he bit me very violently on the shoulder and arm, and struck me with his fists as hard as he could—I got other hurts in the struggle, and cut my knee very violently—after some time a light was brought, and he then said, "Oh forgive me, master"—he had been in my service six months since—immediately he was secured I went down into the area with a policeman, and found the larder door, leading into the passage and up stairs, open—that was secured over night by a latch which only opens from the outside—some wire gauze which had been over it was forced out at one corner, by which means the door was opened—there is a very small circular window under the steps from which a small pane of glass had been broken, and we had pasted a piece of paper over it—that paper was forced through, and the window opened—that could have been done from without, and that I conjecture was the way he got in—he could then force his person into the larder—I found a pair of shoes immediately under that window, which we took up stairs—the prisoner

having no shoes or stockings on, they were put down for him, and he imme
diately put them on and went out of the house in them—he did not claim them exactly—he was searched on being delivered over to the police, and some lucifers and a tap was taken from him with a key to it, which would present the appearance of a pistol—it was exactly the same shape.

COURT. Q. He did not present it to frighten any body? A. He had not much time, for I closed with him immediately—I found him on the first floor, the same floor with the drawing-room and bed-room—he had been one month in my service.

JANE WHITE . I was in Mr. Lodge's service. On the night of the 30th of Nov. I went to bed at half-past ten o'clock—before doing so I secured the house—I saw the window which leads into the larder from the area—that was safe and secure—I held a candle to it and looked at it—the wire gauze before the door was also secure, and the house entirely shut up.
WILLIAM SPONG (police-constable P 96.) I was sent for, and took the prisoner into custody—I searched him, and found on him this tap and two or three lucifer matches.
Prisoner. I asked him to go down in the area and fetch my shoes, which I had left at the door. Witness. I said, "You have no shoes on," and he said, "If you go down into the area you will find them."

HENRY SPARKES . I was in Mr. Lodge's service at this time. I remem
ber his coming home late in the night—I opened the street door about twenty minutes to four o'clock in the morning, and it was then chained.

Prisoners Defence. After I left Mr. Lodge I was in the service of Mr. Aldry; I went to mind his father's house at Brixton, and was there three days; after a fortnight he came home from Ramsgate, and found that two or three things had been taken from his house, which he charged me with steal
ing; he had me taken up, and I was committed to Brixton for two months; Mr. Lodge's lad went and spread it all over Camberwell and Peckham that I was transported, and told Mr. Lodge several things against my character, which he told a gentleman when he went for my character, and when I came out of Brixton I inquired of my brothers and friends where the lad was; they said he had left Mr. Lodge, but since that I was told he had not left, so I went up to Mr. Lodge's, and waited for some time walking up end down in front of the house to catch him; I could not catch him, and about nine o'clock I saw the front door open; I went in, and laid under the sofa in the first room till I saw the lad; I waited to see him, but could not see him; I fell asleep under the sofa, and slept till Mr. Lodge came in, at four o'clock in the morn
ing, when he awoke me; I got up, went down stairs, and unfastened the door ready to run out if any one came; I put my shoes down by the door, and went up stairs to Mr. Lodge's dressing-room to fetch a pitcher of water, Mr. Lodge came and caught me there; when I went down stairs I pushed the wire work away from the safe door to see if there was any pitcher there, and I could not see any thing; I did not touch the window which led into the area; I did not go into the pantry.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

270.
ELIZABETH LEARWOOD was indicted
for unlawfully endeavour
ing to conceal the birth of her child; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Two Months. Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

271.
ALICE YORK was indicted
with stealing 3 knives, value 5s.; 3 forks, 5s.; 1 sheet, 3s.; 2 shirts, 6s.; 1 spoon, 1l. 15s.; and 1 bed
gown, 2s.; the goods of
William Beckford, her master.

WILLIAM BECKFORD , tailor, 70, Hercules-buildings. The prisoner was in my service, and left on the 27th of Nov.—on her leaving I found seven duplicates—I went with them to the pawnbrokers, and found the articles stated, which are mine—the spoon is silver.

GEORGE HERBERT WHARTON , pawnbroker, Westminster-road. These articles were pledged by the prisoner from April to Oct. or Nov.—I have known her four or five years living in situations where they might possess such things—we take in silver from servants we know—it is a constant practice for servants to pledge their master's plate—she has redeemed property—I asked her all that was necessary—the prosecutor's house is not far from ours—she pledged in the names of Rogers and Johnson—"Lambeth" is the address on the tickets—one has South-street, which is a few doors from where we live—we use every precaution, and have been the means of convicting many—we have taken in property to a considerable amount from the prisoner, and it has been redeemed by the owner—all these articles have been redeemed and pledged again three or four times.

WILLIAM BECKFORD
re-examined. I never authorised her to pledge or redeem.
Prisoner's Defence. I intended to make all these things good, but he put me in prison, and I had no opportunity of doing so.

GUILTY . Aged 76.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Four Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

272.
DANIEL CORNALEY was indicted
for stealing 18lbs. weight of rope, value 1s.; the goods of
Mark Brown, in a vessel on the navigable river Thames.

JOHN RIVERS . I am a waterman at Pickle Herring-stairs. On the 28th of Oct I saw the prisoner take some rope out of a lug-boat, and go into Sims' barge, which was alongside, moored under the North Briton brig—he went and stowed it behind some grating—then came out of the barge into the lug-boat, again—took some more rope and put that into the barge, and stowed that away—he came a third time and took some more, and put that away—Sims then came, and I told him—I called Mr. Judge, and gave the prisoner into custody—I am sure it was the same rope that I saw afterwards—till it got to the police-office it was in my sight.

GEORGE WALKER JUDGE (inspector of the Thames-police.) I was called by Rivers, and saw the prisoner—Rivers said he had been stealing some rope—the prisoner said he thought there was no harm in taking a little rope—I saw the lug-boat laden with the same sort of rope as that in the barge.

JOHN BEARD . I am a labourer on Mr. Mark Brown's wharf—I had the care of that lug-boat—I took the rope out of the North Briton into the lug
boat—it was consigned to Mr. Brown—Mr. Burgess had to get it on shore, being a lighterman.

WELLINGTON BURGESS . I hired the craft—the rope was under my con
troul, but consigned to Mr. Brown.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to make a vessel fast—I never touched the rope.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.

273.
WILLIAM CARTER was indicted
for embezzlement, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Four Months.

274.
JOSEPH POULTON was indicted
for stealing 1 purse, value 4d.; and 1 half-sovereign; the property of
Henry James Shrapnell.

HENRY JAMES SHRAPNELL . On the 25th of Oct. I put a half-sovereign in my purse in my jacket pocket, and put it on a chair in the kitchen—there was no person present but the prisoner—I missed the purse and half-sovereign about a quarter before eight—I asked the prisoner if he knew anything about it—he said, "No, he did not"—no one else had been in the room, I am sure, during the whole time—he was not searched; but on Sunday, the 29th, he came to me in the tap-room for 6d. worth of halfpence, and pulled out of his pocket a half-sovereign—I asked him where he got it—he said his master gave it him for wages—that was the money I had lost on the 25th.

JAMES CODRINGTON . I am the prisoner's master. I did not pay the pri
soner any half-sovereign; I paid him 10s. in silver.

JAMES CUNNINGHAM (police-constable V 195.) I was on duty in Wands
worth-road on the 29th of Oct., and received the prisoner in charge—he wanted me to take him to his master—I said I could no—he then pulled out the half-sovereign and said, "Harry, here it the half-sovereign, take it."

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

275.
MARY ANN CARTWRIGHT was indicted
for stealing 3 yards of jean, value 1s. and 1 cloak, 3s.; the goods of
Richard Young, her master.
ELIZA YOUNG . I am the daughter of Richard Young. I missed a woollen cloth boy's cloak and some jean in August—these are them—the prisoner was in our service.
THOMAS ELWOOD , shopman to Mr. Chapman, pawnbroker. I produce this cloak and a piece Of jean—the prisoner pawned the cloak—I cannot say who pawned the jean.
THOMAS DALY (policeman.) I produce a duplicate of the jean, which I got from the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Three Months.

276.
THOMAS ROSS was indicted
for embezzling 8s. 2d.; and that be he had been before convicted of felony.

HENNRY JOHN LEGG . I am a shoemaker; the prisoner was in my service. On the 24th of Oct. I sent him with fourteen pairs of shoes to Mr. Thoma's, in Cheapside—he was to receive 8s. 2d., which he ought to have brought back, and other materials—if he received that money, he did not return.

Prisoner. I never saw you before in my life. Witness. Yes, you did—they were fourteen pair of back-strap shoes, six by nine—the prisoner had been with me a few days over a fortnight—I am positive he is the person.
JOHN STANCOMB . I am foreman to Mr. Thomas. The prisoner brought fourteen pairs of shoes on the 24th of last month—I gave him 8s. 2d., and a dozen pairs of work for his master to manufacture.
Prisoner. Q. Do you know what they were? A. Some were grained patent, and some grey—you gave in fourteen pairs of shoes, and I recollect they were all back-straps.
Prisoner. All I have to say is, that the prosecutor is as false a swearing man as ever swore in his life, and it is a pity such a man should be allowed to take an oath.
THOMAS BALDWIN (police-sergeant L 13.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

277.
HENRY FRENCH was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 5l.; 1 guard-chain, 10s.; and 1 key, 1d.; the goods of
John Henderson, his master.—2nd Count, stating them to be the goods of
Mary Ann Blackmore.

MARY ANN BLACKMORE . I am a widow, and live at Wandsworth. I had a silver watch and a gold chain—I saw them last about two months ago—they were kept in a bureau drawer—I had delivered the bureau to Mr. Hen
derson to mend—I am quite certain the watch and chain were in it—this is my watch and chain.
JOHN HENDERSON . I am a carpenter. I received the bureau, and handed it, in the same state as I received it, to the prisoner, who was in my employ.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I believe, after it was found that a watch had been taken, you spoke to the prisoner? A. Yes—what he said he told me voluntarily, and it was through what he said the watch was found.
JAMES JOHN SNARES . I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned this watch and chain with me.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 37.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

278.
HENRY EBERS was indicted
for stealing 2 boxes, value 1s.; 2 pairs of trowsers, 10s.; 8 shirts, 14s. 6d.; 3 shirt fronts, 3s.; 3 pairs of drawers, 3s. 6d.; 2 night-caps, 1s. 6d.; 3 aprons, 1s. 6d.; 2 scarfs, 1s.; 2 pairs of gloves, 1s.; 1 waistcoat, 6d.; 4 printed books, 19s.; 3 drawings, 6d.; 2 pairs of socks, 1s.; 4 collars, 1s. 4d.; and 1 brace, 1d.; the goods of
George Henry Haworth.

GEORGE HENRY HAWORTH . I am an engineer, and live in York-place, Chelsea. On the 8th of Nov. I sent the prisoner for a box of linen, contain
ing the articles mentioned, from Mr. Spiiler's, at Battersea—he was to return the same day, but he did not—a day or two after I heard something from his wife, and found my things at a beer-shop in Bridge-road, Battersea—nothing had been stolen, but he had got some money lent on them.
NOT GUILTY .

279.
THOMAS NELLYER and
WILLIAM TURNER were indicted for
stealing 33lbs. weight of fat, value 10s., the goods of
Solomon Bennett, the master of Nellyer.

SOLOMON BENNETT . I am a butcher, at St. George's-market. Nellyer was in my employ—it was his duty to take the waste fat to Mr. Brooks's, the tallow-chandler's, Southwark Bridge-road—on the 17th of Nov. I directed him to take some—Turner lived seven or eight feet from my stable-door—I have since seen the fat at the station—I knew it—one part of it I had in my hand several times the same day—it was part of the gut fat, which we use to serve the Jews—I could swear to it.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. I believe you are a Jew? A. Yes—Jews only use gut fat—I serve about a hundred families with gut fat—I know this because it is the rim of a gut fat which I had been using all day—I had a quarter or half a pound of it—it is constantly the case—I do not know how much fat there was for him to take—I have four buys in my shop—they serve customers with fat occasionally.

WILLIAM GUEST (police-constable L 62.) Between seven and eight o'clock in the evening of the 17th I was in Blackfriars-road—I saw the pri
soners

come from Pearl-row, in the direction of where the prosecutor lives—Turner was carrying a basket, in which was a sack of fat—I followed them to the foot of Blackfriars-bridge, on the Surrey side, where I stopped Turner—Nellyer walked away—I asked Turner what he had got on his head—he said some fat that he had brought from the Old Kent-road, from a carrier's cart, and was going to take it to Mr. Gantly's, in Fox and Knot-court—he appeared confused, and I took him to the station—soon after another officer brought in Nellyer—he said where he lived—I went to the prosecutor's.
Cross-examined by MR. NEALE. Q. Who brought in Nellyer? A. Brooks.

COURT. Q. Was the place you took him in the direction from the prose
cutor's to the Southwark Bridge-road? A. No.

JAMES BROOKS (police-constable L 118.) I was in the Blackfriars-road—I saw the two prisoners coming in a direction from the prosecutor's—Turner had a basket, with something in it—they were making their way to Black
friars-bridge—at the foot of the bridge Guest stopped them—while he was questioning them, Nellyer walked away—I followed, stopped him, and asked him where he was going with the other man—he said he knew nothing of him.
NOT GUILTY .

280.
THOMAS PEARSON was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counter
feit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined One Year.

281.
CHARLES FIELD,
THOMAS EVANS,
DANIEL CARROLL , and
DAVID BENTLIFF were indicted for
stealing 1 box, value 2l.; 5 shifts, 5l.; 9 petticoats, 4l.; 2 night-gowns, 4l.; 1 pair of stays, 2l.; 4 pairs of drawers, 4l.; 42 pairs of stockings, 15l.; 45 handkerchiefs, 30l.; 8 veils, 90l.; 10 pairs of cuffs, 3l.; 6 wreaths of artificial flowers, 2l.; 17 napkins, 4l.; 19 doyleys, 1l.; 46 towels, 1l. 13s.; the goods of
Sir Richard Paul Jodrell, Baronet.—2nd Count, stating them to be the goods of
James Butler.

SARAH BALLS . I am lady's-maid in the service of Sir Richard Paul Jodrell, baronet. The family were at Brighton in Oct. last, and left on the 28th, by an early train—I assisted in packing up the luggage, particularly Lady Jodrell's wearing apparel, in a large black leather trunk, with brass nails—I put in some veils, some dozens of silk stockings, from thirty to forty pocket-handkerchiefs, worth four or five guineas each—the whole was worth about 200l.—Charles Crocker, the second footman, locked the box—I saw the box in the drawing-room after it was corded—I have not seen it since—I came by the same train as the family, and the servants were to follow—two men and two maids came by the same train as the luggage.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How large was the box? A. I do not know exactly—I have seen others as big, and with brass nails—it was like a great many trunks—I did not see it when it quitted the house—I should say it was not uncorded to put anything in—one of the housemaids had the key—most of the things belonged to Lady Jodrell—there were some very fine damask dinner napkins, for her ladyship's own use—I did not see either the napkins or the doyleys put into the box—when I last saw them they were in the room where the box was, and were to be put in.

FANNY HEARNDON . I am housemaid at Sir Richard Jodrell's. On the 27th of Oct. I assisted Balls in packing a large box—I put in it twenty-six chamber towels, seventeen dinner napkins, nineteen doyleys—Sir Richard

had left the house a few days before—I saw the box locked by Crocker—these things were then in it—I took the key of him and brought it up to town—I did not see it corded—it is my lady's box—I have not seen it since—I came up with the servants by the same train as the box.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you put these things at the top? A. No; about the middle—I left the box in charge of Balls to put the other things in—I standing by when she put them in—I came up by the third class train which left Brighton at two—I do not know what time we arrived at London-bridge—the men servants were in the same train—I have not been told to say that I do not know what time I arrived—the policeman has not said any thing to me about time, nor told me that time was very im
portant—I have not been asked before what time we arrived.

CHARLES CROCKER . I am Sir Richard Jodrell's footman. On the 28th of Oct. I corded some of the luggage and carried it down stairs—in particular I corded a large box with brass nails and oval top—I locked it—I did not see what it contained—it was corded across, and a card was on it—I gave the key to Hearndon—I came up by the same train as the luggage, and some of the servants, Hearndon, Jeffrey, and Applegate—I saw the box after the arrival of the train at London-bridge—the number of boxes were all right then—this box was a heavy one—I saw it placed on a van, belonging to Butler, to be conveyed to Portland-place—I lifted it out of the luggage-van of the railway and saw it placed on the right-hand corner of the van behind, close to the tail board—there was a large hamper and wine, and other things, on the corre
sponding side—Butler's little child was sitting on the hamper—we arrived at London-bridge about five o'clock, and got every thing loaded on the van about half-past five—on leaving London-bridge the van turned up Union-street—Applegate went with it—I arrived at Portland-place about half-past six—before the luggage—I went in a cab with the two female servants—the lug
gage arrived some time after me, and was emptied out of the van into the hall—I assisted in unloading it—when I took it up stairs I found the box in question was not there—I have not seen it since.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You did not pay any more at
tention to this trunk than the others? A. I had more to do with it than the others—I am certain there were brass nails in it—there were five trunks of this description, but only half the size of this—it went by a ran belonging to Stevens, from the house at Brighton to the railway—Applegate went with the van to the station—I did not see it moved from the van on to the railway—there is a place to put the luggage in, and that is locked—it was full a quarter after two before the train left, and it ought to have left a quarter before two—I looked at the clock at the station at Brighton when we got there—it was half-past one—I did not notice when we left.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Why do you recollect that you lifted this trunk? A. One of the policemen came and told me to leave it for one of the porters—the other trunks were black leather and nails—I be
lieve there has been a reward of 10l. offered for the discovery of this box—I do not know whether it is to be paid on the conviction—we applied at the railway terminus the same night—the other footman and the butler went to know if a box was left there—I said I was certain I placed it on the van, but Lady Jodrell wished them to go.

HENRY APPLEGATE . I am footman to Sir Richard Jodrell. On the 28th of Oct. I came with the luggage by the afternoon train from Brighton—we arrived at the terminus at London-bridge about five, as near as possible—we were detained nearly half an hour getting the luggage together before we started—there were thirteen large boxes and five small ones, eighteen in all—the

van was waiting inside the shed, where the carnage drew up—I saw this box placed on Butler's van on the right hand side—there was an imperial placed across the ran, and just against it was this trunk—it was placed on the other packages that were in the bed of the ran—I could reach it very well as I stood—I accompanied the ran from the terminal to Portland-place—it was a very cold day, and we all stopped just by the station to get some refreshment—we stopped a second time at the Queen's Head, in Charlotte-street, Blaokfriars, on the left hand side—we proceeded on, and just before we arrived at the Queen's Head there is a street which tarns out of Char
lotte-street, called King William-street—we staid at the Queen's Head a minute or two, just while we drunk a pint of beer—while we were there we were spoken to by a man named Wells, a hair-dresser—on going on I saw a person resembling Carroll, on the left hand side of the van, the other side to where the box was—I did not see any one that I believe to be any of the other prisoners—Carroll was close to the van when I first saw him—he passed by the van and horse, and stopped at a window and looked as though he was Heading something till we got to him, and then he went on—we passed him again, and be pasted and re-passed us—we left the station a little before six—we staid about the same time at both public-houses, had some beer, and the two women bad some brandy-and-water, and we eat some biscuit which we had in our pockets—I walked by the van—I did not miss the box till we got home, about a quarter to seven.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You did not go all the rest of the journey without refreshments? A. Yes, we did—I did not treat any ladies as we went along.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Did you go to the railway the same evening to inquire about the box? A. Yes—I went with Brown, the butler—he is not here—we started in a cab directly we had taken the lug
gage up stairs—a short man could have reached the box in the van—Carroll was dressed as a groom's undress, with a fur cap on—it was just as the gas was lighting—I had never seen him before—he was the only person who passed at the time—we came from the terminus along Tooley-street, down Union-street, across Blackfriars-road, over Waterloo-bridge, to Portland-place.

THOMAS BUTLER , carman, Tottenham-court-road. On the 28th of Oct. I received instructions to go to the terminus of the Brighton Railway at Lon
don-bridge—I got there about an hour before the train arrived, which was about its usual time, or five minutes after—I remember the luggage being put on the van—I loaded it as well as I could—I could not do it last enough—there were five porters, and they said, "Make baste, we expect another train in"—there was a hamper on the near side of the van, touching the tail-ladder—it was a middle-sized hamper belonging to the coachman, and came from the coachman's stable—I took it there again—my little child, six years old, was with me—he sat between the hamper and the next thing forwards, with his head towards the horses—I did not take particular notice where this box was placed—I know there was a box, the imperial was placed across the van, and this was behind it—I cannot say whether it was the box which was lost or not—four servants came by the train—thay had refreshments, but I did not leave the van then—I afterwards stopped for refreshment in Charlotte-street—I went inside the Queen's Head for a pint of half-and-half—it was brought to the door outside—I left the footman and my little boy in charge of the van, which was very near the house—while I was there I saw a person answering the description of Bentliff—I cannot swear to him—he had not the same dress that he has on now—from his general appearance he is the most

like the one I saw—it if only a resemblance in his form—I have recol
lection so as to form any opinion of him—he was dressed in fustain clothes, and his jacket came rather low down.

THOMAS BURFOOT , chimney-sweeper, William-street, Borough. About six o'clock on Saturday evening, the 28th of Oct., I was in William-street—I saw four men about twenty yards from Charlotte-street, about forty yards from the Queen's Head, coming towards me—two were carrying a large black feather trunk with beats nails, and a rope across and across—I waited till they got close to my door—one was then a-head, and another behind by the two that carried tie trunk—when he came up with the others he made an oberservation which I could not hear—I saw one running run up York-street in the direction of the cab-stand, leaving the other three—two were carrying the trunk, and the other was close by—they went on to the end of William-street, crossed George-street to the corner of Robert-street—the trunk was put down under the wall by the beer-shop at the Corner—two men good by the trunk, and one man was standing opposite the other two—the cab came up William-street to the corner of Robert-streets—the two men and the man who went after the cab came together, and the two that carried the trunk brought it to the cab—they all four assisted to put it on the top of the cab where the cab-man sits—I went behind, and took the number of the cab, 1360—two got inside, and one got on the top—the other was be
