hind—they drove on to the end of Robert-street—I followed it—I saw if stop—they were geing to turn down Edward-street, but. there being no thorough
fare, they turned, round in Edward-street, and two men got down about six yards from the coal-shed—they got up again, and drove up Edward-street to Blackfriars-road—I saw Thomas Jones, belonging to the coal-shed—I looked for a policeman, but could not find one—I gave information to the polioeman, and described the parties—Field and Carroll were two of the four men—I have only little belief as to the other two—one of the others was dressed in a dark frock-coat and one in a kind of fustian coat with buttons—I am not positive about their dress, it being night.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Were you always positive about Carrolt and Field? A. Yes—I saw them for about ten minutes—I never saw them before—it was not very dark, because there was a very fine gasr-light theft—they passed nearly opposite me—Carroll had a cap on—I did not give information that night because I could not see a polioeman—I walked about for half an hour and looked for one—I did not go over the bridge—I first made a communication to the policeman about mid-day on Sunday to Branford—I saw him in Gravel-lane—I heard of the reward of 10l. at the station—I do not know what is to be my share—I first saw Field and Carroll after this again about one o'clock on Thursday morning at the station—Branford fetched me to them—I had to get out of my bed—the prisoners were sitting by a fire in the station with a policeman—there were five or six policemen there all in uniform—Branford told them to stand up, and said, "Are these the men?"—I said I believed Field and Carroll were two of the men, and I waa not so certain about the others—I entertained the same opinion then as to Field and Carroll that I do now—I did not say at the station that I was certain as to Field—I became certain after—I have not said before that Carroll had a hat on.
JONATHAN WHICHER (police-sergeaut A 27.) I was employed to offer a reward on the Monday following the robbery—the hills, were circulated on the Tuesday.
THOMAS JONES , Union-place, Edward-street, Blackfriars-road. Between six and seven o'clock on Saturday evening, the 28th of Oct., a cab came into

Edward-street—there was no thoroughfare—one man got out of cab—I did not see any man the cab—a man asked if there was thoroughfare—I said no—there was a large box on the cab with brass nails and a rope tied round it longways and round it again, and a white card under the rope—I did not take any notice of the man.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. What is your age? A. Fourteen—Barfoot applied to me directly the cab was gone—I have talked about the brass nails and the card since, but not the rope—he aaked me if there was a card on the top—I only saw it a moment.
Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. Did you not notice two brass handles on the box? A. No, nor two brass plates—I did look at it at all.

SAMUEL RATTON . I am a cab-driver. About six o'clock int the evening of the 28th of Oct. I was called by a man, who said he had got a fare for me—he told me to go to the corner of Robert-street and George-street—he rode on the box with me—I went to ther corner of Robert-street—he rode were three more men—they put the box on the cab, two of them got in-side, and one rode with me—they ordered me to drive to the Borough, down Holland-street—I passed a little way, and went to turn down Edward-street—some inquiries were made of Jones—I was told there was no thoroughfare, and orders were given to me to drive up the Blackside—when, I drove to the street—I was afterwards told to go straight down Bankside—when I got half way, they said they were going down the New Kent-road—I drove to the corner of New-street and Lyon-street—I was told previously to drive in the direction of Blackfriars-bridge, which was from the Kent-read—when I got there they had no money to pay me—they took the box off, and one of the four stopped with me—I waited about three minutes till they brought me 2s. 6d.—my fare was 2s., but I carried three persons—they went down New-street—when I got there, there was a fourth man—I did not see what became of him—when we left Edward-street, I suppose he must have ridden behind the cab—I found him when I arrived—I have only a slight recollection of Field being the man who rode outside—he sat on the roof—we did not get into con-versation—he sat above me—it was a dressed cab—it was not Field who called the cab—the man who called me was dreeeed in a fustian jacket and dark trowsers, and a hat—one of them had a cap—it was a black leather trunk, with brass nails, and in oval top, and a cord round it—the man who rode at the top assisted in putting it up, and staid with me while the others went—it was a very dark, dirty street where I pulled up—I think two of the men were in jackets, Field in a black frock-coat, and one in a Chesterfield wrapper.

JOSEPH THOMAS WELLS , hair-dresser, Charlotte-street. I live about three doors from the Queen's Head, on the same side of the street—on the evening of the 28th ef Oct. I saw a van oppoeite the Queen's Head in Charlotte-street—I saw Applegate—I went into the public house, and remained abou, half a minute—as I came from the door I saw the van loaded with trunks and a little boy—it attracted my attention—I saw some persons about of bed character—I went back, and spoke to Applegate, who was in the public-house—the child was looking towards Blackfriar-road over the boxes—I saw some persons about—I believe Field was one of them—I cannot speak to the others—I did not notice how many persons there were about, or how they were dressed—I saw Field come from a tobacconist's shop next door to the public-house, and speak to a short young man—I took notice of the van being laden—it was not laden up to the tail-board.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARKOCK. Q. Then there were a great many persons about the public-house? A. Not a great many, three or four—Appleby and Butler were both inside the shop at the same time—there were no females in the cart—I did not see Appleby near the van while Butler was inside—I had never seen the man I take for Field before—I do not swear to him—my be
lief is that it was him—I at first hesitated to say that he was the man, but when they got into the dock I believed it was him—I did not hear about the reward.

WILLIAM DERRING (police-constable M 79.) I produce a Taglioni coat that was shown to Evans—he said it was his—about one o'clock in the morn
ing of the 2nd of Nov. I assisted in apprehending the prisoners—they were all at the Princess of Wales public-house, in the London-road—there were other officers with me—Cuddy went in—Carroll lodged at Cadny-terrace, Kent-road—I searched his lodgings with Terry—I found a fustian jacket, trowsers, and a cap there—I believe they have been taken into the coun
try by mistake—Terry had the care of them—we inquired of the prisoners at the station where they lived—Evans said at No. 1, Bond-street, Carroll said, 32, Bond-street, and the others gave addresses—I went to them, and they were not right—I know Carroll's mother lived at 32, Bond-street—she said her son had left her for three weeks before—I told Field, in presence of the others, that I wanted him for stealing a trunk from a van in Charlotte-street, Blackfriars-road—Carroll said he had been ill for a week before, and had not been out—Bentliff said that he was at work at Lewisham, and was paid at twenty minutes to six that evening—I had not seen him for a fortnight before in the London-road—Field did not say where he had been—I had seen Bent
liff several times during the three months.
MR. FLOOD. Q. Carroll told you he had been ill? A. Yes, for a week previous to his being apprehended, that he was taken ill on Friday, and had not been out.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDE ROAST. Q. Did you take Bentliff? A. No, I apprehended Field—they came out of a public-house—they were all appre
hended at the same time—Evans and Field came out first—we took them—Carroll was then called out, and given to another constable—we then crossed—Cuddy went back to the public-house, and took Bentliff.
Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. When did you first state that Carroll said he had been ill a week before? A. I did not state that at the Hall—I was not asked.

JAMES CUDDY (policeman.) I assisted in the prisoners' apprehension—I stood at the public-house door—Evans and Field came out—we called Carroll out, and another officer took him—I afterwards went and took Bentliff—they were all in amongst other persons in front of the bar—I believe I had seen Carroll a night or two before, but I am not certain—I had seen Field.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDIROAST. Q. Do you mean to swear that you saw the four prisoners together at that public-house? A. I do—I did not go into the house to apprehend Bentliff—I stood at the door, and called him out—this was about one o'clock on Thursday morning.

ROBERT BRAKFORD (policeman.) I was one of the party who apprehended the prisoners—I had seen Carroll within the week before that—I think it was on the Saturday evening, about seven or eight o'clock, in Blackman-street, walking with another young man, and they went into the Mint—I fol
lowed them home, to see where Carroll went—that was after I had heard of this robbery.
NOT GUILTY .

282.
JOHN WESTWOOD and
EDWARD ELLIS were indicted for
stealing 2 saddles, value 2l. 10s.; 1 pair of reins, 4s.; 2 pair of trace, 1l.; 1 pair of harness, 10s.; and 1 breeching, 10s.; the goods of
Joseph Cheek their master.

JOSEPH CHEEK , bricklayer, Commercial-road, Lambeth. I rent No. 11 arch of Waterloo-bridge, in which I keep horses and harness—the prisoners were in my employ—on Friday, the 10th of Nov., Westwood was employed at the arch all day to clean the harness—he had no business to remove any without orders—he left me on the 13th—I missed the things stated on the 12th—I saw the prisoners again in custody on the 18th, charged with taking the harness—they denied it—I have never seen it since.

Cross-examined by MR. NEALE. Q. Have you always given the same account of this? A. Yes; I swear I have never said that the prisoners left without giving me notice—I asked them on the Saturday when I paid them if they were satisfied—they said, "Yes"—I did not tell them I did not want them any more—I may have said that I missed the things on the 13th—I missed them on the 12th and 13th too, and on the 13th I sent to make inquiries about it—they were taken on the Friday—the arch is locked every night at eight o'clock, and another gate outside is locked—there is a regular watchman on the premises—I leave about eight o'clock—there is only one entrance—the other end is bricked up—I had six or seven men at that time—I have all their names in my book—they had been working with me about a month—the prisoners, I believe, worked the shortest—eight o'clock is the time for closing the vault—I was there about five o'clock on Friday evening, and told the prisoners to do them up—I came back and found Jeffreys and two others at work, but the prisoners were gone—I remained there about half an hour, seeing the work done—the harness that was taken hung up on the right hand as you go in—I keep horses and carriages there as well—when I left it at half-past six o'clock I left the door open, and left the men that were there and my son—he always stops to close the door—beyond the door are high outer gates, which are kept locked—a man named Griffin was in my employ, and worked for me a week after the prisoners left—he was at work on Friday the 10th—he comes at half-past seven o'dock, and stops till eight o'clock—I or my son are there to receive him, and take away the key—I always look round the place, lock it up, and take the key—it is my son's duty to look round as well as mine, but I do not look round on a Monday—most likely my son took the key home on the Friday—I saw it next morning at seven o'clock hanging on a nail by the fire-place in my front parlour—no one could get at it—I give it to the first that comes in the morning—I pay my men at my house every Saturday night—they do not come into the room where the key hangs, and I do not think they knew where it was kept—they were paid at the door—I never told Griffin I would give him two guineas if he would reveal the real thieves, nor was any sum mentioned by me or my wife in my presence—I never asked him to try and find the thieves—I dis
charged him last Saturday week, as he said he was going to drive for another person—I did not see him last Friday—I did not say any thing to Mr. Wise about the real thieves—I have not treated her—we had our dinner together—a man named Brown, who has worked for me on and off nearly two years, was working for me at the time of the robbery—I discharged him last Saturday—I have not seen him since—it was about two o'clock on Sunday the 12th that I went into the vault and missed the harness—I had not been there for three or four days—I did not then suspect the prisoners—I charged them with it on the Saturday following—I went to the nearest place, which

was Mr. Wise's—I thought tney drigfct nave seen persons go by with harness, and they stood for a while and thete said they did so on Friday evening—I have not accused any one else of this—there were more that I thought had some portion of it, but how I could not tell—I never accused them, because they absconded—one was Robertson—I cannot recollect the other's name—I did not employ the men regularly—I paid them on Saturday.

HENTRY JEFFREYS . On the 10th of Nov. I was working for the prosecu
tor, at No. 11 arch, Waterloo-bridge—the prisoners were at work there, from six till half-past six o'clock—I saw them leave together—Ellis had two saddles, a breeching, and a pair of hames, on his left shoulder—Westwood assisted him in carrying them out—I saw them leave the arch with it—they did not come back—I was there till very near nine o'clock.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been in the prosecutor's employ? A. Twelve months—I went to work about seven o'clock on Friday morning I called at my master's house first for the key—he gave it to ne at the door—I generally call for it—if master is not up, I do not take it, but wait till he gires it me—I did not know where it was kept—the two prisoners were in the stable on Friday evening, when I returned at five o'clock—we all came in about five—master lets out cabs—the two prisoners and two more men were at work—I remained there till they left, without going away—no one but us five were in the stable after five, except my master—his son came in with us—my master came about half-past five, and left—I did not see his son go with him, but I did not see him after master left—matter returned about half-past six, or a quarter to seven—the prisoners were then gone—no one but me was there—I did not tell my master or his son that the pri
soners had gone away with the harness—I we all three came away together—my syoung to master locked up the stable—master had then gone on about ten yards a-head—he could not have heard his son locking the door—this was from half-past eight till nice—when master left at half-past six, it was to see after see prisoners and the other men—I had to do their work—I did not know their names or addresses—I called them by nick-names, Kingston Jack and Fiddler—I gave the others no names—I cannot tell at what time theother men left—the last time I saw them was at five, when we all came back—I have not seen them since—the prisoners had no right to take the harness out of the stable, without they were told by master or his son—I did not hear them tell then to take it—master used to tell them to take it to his house, to be put away—it was new harness, and I thought they were going to take it to my master's—I told my master about it on the Sunday, when he spoke to me about it at the stable—before I worked for the prosecutor I worked for my father, who is a plumber, and drove vans—the harness used to be fetched back when it was wanted, and it was wanted on Sunday—I have heard nothing about a reward—I do not know Brown or Griffin—about nine men were employed about the stable on the Friday—the arch is fastened by a padlock—it was quite secure that night, and also in the morning—I never saw my young master, or any one, draw the staple when they went in, and push it in again.
COURT. Q. What light had you in the stable? A. Four candles and large fire.

SUSANNAH WISE . I live in Commercial-road, Lambeth, very near the arches of Waterloo-bridge. About six o'clock on Friday evening, I saw Ellis with a saddle on his shoulder—he stopped and looked in my face, and I saw the curl on the side of his face—he was carrying harness—it was slipping, and Westwood went and helped it up—I was afraid of my winddw—I saw the brass of the harness—I can swear more to Ellis, because he came to my shop frequently, and the other not so often.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you get your living? A. In a shop in the general line—my house is next door but one to the stable—I swear to Elliis, and have every reason to believe Westwood was the other man—I saw the side of his face, and it was nearly covered with the saddle—I have heard nothing of any reward—I have not been dining with or treated by Mr. Cheek to-day.
JAMES BROOK (policeman.) I took Westwood, on the 18th, at Mr. Cheek's house—he said he knew nothing about it.

WILLIAM GUEST (policeman.) I took Ellis on the 18th of Nov., and told him what for—he said he knew nothing at all about it—when he got a short distance from the house he ran away—I pursued and secured him—in taking him to the station he said others ought to be taken as well as him.

MR. CHEEK re-examined. I went away twice—I went home to get my tea—I then came back and went away again—I was not there when the door was locked—the harness had not been taken home for the last fortnight—it was not taken home regularly, unless I ordered it.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

WESTWOOD—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

ELLIS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

div0.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 11TH OF DECEMBER.
